casebody.data:
Lessee of Thomas Cochran’s Heirs v. David Loring. Under the ordinance of 1787, the governor and judges had power to adopt from the statutes of other states, attachment as well as other laws. Though a law is imperfect in its details, it is not void, unless it is so imperfect as to render it impossible to execute it; hut the imperfections in its details may he supplied by rules of court. The judgment of a court having jurisdiction of the subject-matter, cannot be impeached collaterally. In proceedings under our attachment laws, the service of the writ by the attachment of property, confers jurisdiction upon the court. After jurisdiction is acquired, the court may proceed to the final disposition of the case, and sale of the property attached, notwithstanding the death of the debtor before judgment. *410This is a writ of error to the Superior Court of Hamilton county. The original action in this case was instituted by the lessor^ of the plaintiff, against the defendant, for the recovery of certain premises in the city of Cincinnati. The declaration was filed on the 14th May, 1845, and is in usual form. To this declaration the defendants pleaded the general issue, and at the October term of the court, 1846, the case was, by agreement of parties, submitted to the court, and on hearing, the court found the issue joined in favor of the defendant, and entered judgment accordingly. The object of this proceeding is to reverse the judgment so rendered. Upon the trial of the case a bill of exceptions was allowed, from which the following statement of facts is extracted: The plaintiff, in support of his title, proved that Thomas Cochran formerly resided in Cincinnati, Ohio, and was then the legal owner of the land described in the consent rule in this cause. That he so resided in Cincinnati up to 3d January, 1801, when he left that place to go to and reside in Natchez, Mississippi. Plaintiff also put in evidence, subject to all objections as to admissibility and legal effect of the matters therein contained, the following agreed statement of facts: “ It is agreed, that upon the trial of these causes, it shall be admitted that Thomas Cochran, the legal owner of the land in controversy, left Cincinnati, Ohio, to go to and reside in Natchez, Mississippi, on 3d January, 1801. That his wife, Phebe, and their children, went with said Thomas from Cincinnati, and all arrived at Natchez on 5th March, 1801, such children being Isabella, William, Phebe and Matilda. That said Thomas Cochran remained at Natchez until his death, which happened on 28th or 29th June, 1801; leaving said Isabella, William, Phebe and Matilda his only heirs at law. *411Said Isabella then being about twenty years of age; said Wil liam about 18 years of age; said Phebe about 12 years of age; and said Matilda about 8 years of age. That said Isabella married David Mickey, 27th December, 1806. That he died July 31st, 1810. That said Isabella married Nathaniel Nichols, on 6th March, 1813. That he died 4th November, 1813. That said Isabella married Orlando Lane, 7th June, 1821. That said Isabella died 17th June, 1834. That said lessors of plaintiff, David C. Mickey and Nathaniel S. Nichols, are her sons, and only heirs at law. That said David C. Mickey was born 1st December, 1803. and said Nathaniel S. Nichols was born January 14th, 1814. That said Isabella resided with her said husbands, in Mississippi and Louisiana, until her death. That said David C. Mickey and Nathaniel S. Nichols were born in and have always resided in Mississippi; and their said mother was a resident of said state, from the time of her arrival there until her death, with the exception of a short residence in Loiuisana, in the year 1813. That said William Cochran resided in Mississippi from the time of his arrival there until his death, in 1833. That the heirs of said William Cochran are the lessors of the plaintiff, Ann Matilda, the wife of Walter R. Puckett, John and Thomas N. Cochran. That said Ann Matilda was born in Mississippi, 20th August, 1816, and has always resided in that state. That she married, before the commencement of these actions, the said Walter R. Puckett. That said John Cochran and Thomas N. Cochran were born in Mississippi, and have always resided in that state.. That said Matilda, the daughter of said Thomas Cochran, married John Montgomery, October 17th, 1811. That said Matilda has resided in Mississippi, from her first arrival there to the commencement of these actions. *412It is further agreed, that the premises claimed by the defendants respectively, were sold under certain proceedings in at tachment, in the case of Smith and Findlay v. Thomas Coch ran, in the Hamilton common pleas, to the several purchasers, and at the times and in manner in said proceedings set forth. That said purchasers respectively took possession of the premises purchased immediately thereafter; and they, and those under them, have ever since held the same, claiming in their own right.” . Plaintiff also put in evidence (subject as aforesaid) the dep ositions of' various witnesses, tending to prove that the said Thomas Cochran died at the time above mentioned — that the lessors of the plaintiff were, together with Phebe Bowie, the heirs at law of the said Thomas Cochran — and that his said children were beyond the State of Ohio when their right of 'action (if any) to recover the lands in question accrued — and that they, and the heirs of Isabella and William, after their decease, remained out of this state until the year 1840, with the exception of the said Isabella, who visited Cincinnati, Ohio, in May, 1827, on her way from Natchez, with her husband, on a visit to the State of Yermont. And thereupon the plaintiff rested his case. The defendant then put in evidence the transcript of records, and docket and minute entries, and affidavit, in the casé of James Smith and James Findlay against said Thomas Cochran. And it was proved that the clerk’s certificate, appended to said transcript, was true. It was admitted by plaintiff (subject to the objection that parol evidence was not admissible to prove the fact) that the said writ of attachment was issued on or after 2d February, 1801, and that the writ was executed before the return of it. And it was admitted by the defendant, that the court of common pleas for Hamilton county adjourned on 21st November, 1800, and did not meet again until 3d February, 1801. The defendant also proved that a notice of the pendency of said attachment suit was inserted in the Western -Spy, a public *413newspaper published in Cincinnati aforesaid, three times, namely : on.the 20th March, 1802, on 27th March, 1802, and on 3d. April, 1802. It was also proved by the defendant, that diligent search had been made in all the numbers of -the said newspaper, from the commencement of the year 1801 to 20th March, 1802, and that no earlier notice of the pendency of said attachment suit was inserted in the said newspaper. Also that there was no other public newspaper published in the said territory as early as 1801. The defendant also proved that diligent search had been made in Kentucky, for a notice of the pendency of said attachment. That the Kentucky Herald, printed at Lexington, was the only public newspaper in Kentucky which, in the • years 1801 and 1802, contained notices of judicial proceedings in Ohio. That during that period several notices were inserted in the Kentucky Herald, in attachment cases, from Ohio, and Hamilton county, Ohio, in which Jacob Burnet was the attorney for the plaintiffs. That said Jacob Burnet was the attorney for the plaintiffs in the said attachment proceeding, in said court of common pleas. That said public newspaper, called the Kentucky Herald, was published at Lexington aforesaid, from the year 1795 to the year 1806. That no notice of the pendency of said attachment was inserted in the Kentucky Herald up to the month of September, 1801; but the numbers of that paper published afterward could not be found, although diligent search had been made for them, except two copies issued in 1805 and 1806. The defendant also put in evidence certified copies, from the recorder’s office, of the following deeds: Deed dated 28th April, 1810. Conveyance of said land by the auditors under said attachment to James Findlay. Deed not attested, but duly acknowledged before John Mahard, a justice of the peace for Hamilton county. Conveyance of said land, dated 2d November, 1829, from' said James Findlay and his wife to the Bank of the United States. *414Conveyance of said land, dated 30th December, 1831, from .the said bank to the said David Loring, the defendant. From the transcript of the record offered in evidence by the defendant, it appeared that in February, 1801, a writ of attachment issued out of the court, at the instance of Smith and Findlay, against Thomas Cochran, setting forth “ that it hath been sufficiently testified that Thomas Cochran is indebted to said Smith and Findlay in the sum of $39, and that said Thomas Cochran is not a resident of said territory,” com manding the officers to attach all and singular the lands and tenements, goods, etc., of defendant, and make due return, etc.: said writ bearing teste as of the 21st day of November, 1800. The writ was returned, showing an attachment and seizure of the premises in question. The record further shows 'that the defendant was regularly called and defaulted at four successive terms of the court; that auditors were appointed at the February term, 1802, to audit the claims against the defendant and make due report thereof, and that at the December term, 1805, the auditors did make report, and thereupon the court granted judgment and directed an order of sale to issue. (Some years subsequent an amended record was made by order of the court, and which was also given in evidence, showing a judgment and ■order in full.j The auditors proceeded and sold the property in August, 1806, and at the August term, 1810, two of them made a report setting forth a sale of the premises, to whom, and at what price, and that they had made a deed therefor to the purchaser; and thereupon the court approved of and confirmed said report, and dismissed the parties without day. Independent ,of • the record, the defendant exhibited an affi davit and praecipe for a writ, dated on the 30th day of January, 1801, and filed, as it appeared from an indorsement on the back, on the second day of February, 1801, setting forth the indebtedness of the defendant to the plaintiffs in the sum of $39, and his non-residence; which was objected to by the plaintiffs. “ *415Upon this testimony the court adjudged that the plaintiffs had made out a prima fade case, but that the defendant had proved that the legal title to the land in controversy had passed by the said proceedings and deed to said James Eindlay; and thereupon rendered judgment for the defendant. The errors assigned are as follows: “ The said superior court of Cincinnati decided that the defendants had the legal title to the land in controversy, which had passed by the (so called) attachment proceedings and deed referred to in the reoord, and by reason of said decision, manifest injury has been sustained by the plaintiff in error. “ And there is further error in this, that the judgment aforesaid was given for the said defendant in error, but ought to have been given for the said plaintiff in error.” Corry & Russell, and McLean Gwynne, for plaintiff in error, made the following points:

I. Laws adopted by the governor and judges — Efficacy of.

1. A law adopted by the governor and judges, enacting that a new and extraordinary judicial proceeding should be conducted as directed by another law, was inoperative, if such other law was not properly adopted and published.

2. Such a proceeding could not, upon this expression of the legislative will, be conducted as it would have been, if the lawmaking power had merely authorized the proceeding, without intending to direct the mode of conducting it.

To declare that, under such a law, the court may appoint proxies to-try the case, and that all the proceedings, the sale and the conveyance, shall be just as the court please, would be to make a law which the law-making power did not contemplate.

II. Issue oe writs.

1. A single judge of the court of common pleas could not, in vacation, take an affidavit, and issue a writ of attachment thereon, unless specially empowered by law to do so.

*4162. The clerk of the court could not, under a power given him to issue writs on praecipes, issue- a writ which the court was authorized to issue upon an affidavit, bringing a case within the provisions of a law authorizing a special judicial proceeding.

III. Jurisdiction or courts.

1. Over the subject-niatter. When a statute authorizes the issue of a writ of attachment, upon a case being made by affidavit, the court has no jurisdiction to issue the writ, without such affidavit having been first made.

2. Over the person, when necessary. The territorial law of 1795 is said to have authorized the issue of a writ for the attachment of lands upon an affidavit of the plaintiff. It did not direct the occupant of the land to be turned out or notified of the proceeding. The law did not authorize the court to do anything before the expiration of a notice to the defendant to appear ; but it is said that after such notice, the' law authorized the rendition of a judgment, and a general administration of the absentee’s estate for the benefit of all the defendant’s creditors who might come in and claim. The court had no jurisdiction to render a judgment for the plaintiff, and adjudicate upon the claims of the other creditors, and order a sale of the defendant’s lands to satisfy the same, until notice had been given to the defendant, as required by the law, to appear and defend. This law is different from later attachment laws.

IV. Jurisdiction or courts over the subject-matter and the person — when presumed — how proved and disproved.

1. The jurisdiction of a court exercising a' summary and special jurisdiction is not presumed, but must be .proved aliwrude, if the record does not show it.

2. When a statute requires the record of all judicial proceedings to set forth the process to appear, a public citation in lieu of such process should be set forth in the record.

3. It is well settled that when the record does not expressly allege the facts necessary to give jurisdiction over the person, *417in an adversary proceeding, it may be proved by the party sought to be affected by the judgment, that he had, no day in court.

4. The court rendering judgment in such case has assumed that the defendant is in court; and where judgment is rendered against a dead man, the court also assumes that the defendant is in court.

Proof of the death of the defendant, before judgment, shows that the assumption of the court that he was living was un foundedit proves that there was no defendant in court.

The technical rule erroneously supposed to affirm that one not actually a party to the proceedings cannot deny express and positive allegations in the record that he was a party, does not apply to mere assumptions.

Although the record shows-that the court, assuming the defendant to be alive, orders the sheriff to levy upon his lands, it may be shown in a collateral proceeding that the defendant was dead when the court assumed that he was living. It may also be assigned in a writ of error, as an error in fact.

If evidence be inadmissible to rebut a mere presumption, afortiori, it is inadmissible to contradict the express allegation in the record that the writ of attachment was issued in November term, 1800 (which was before the affidavit was sworn).

5. According to principle, and the best modern authorities,, no man can be affected by adversary proceedings to which he was not a party; and this rule cannot be neutralized by any forms, pretenses, or allegations whatsoever.

Y. Jurisdiction or courts — When exercised; what is a valid.trial and judgment.

1. A law adopted by the ■ governor and judges, is said to have authorized a new and extraordinary judicial proceeding, without directing the mode of trial. Such trial must have been by jury.

2. When a court having jurisdiction over the subject-matter and the parties, is authorized to try the case by jury, and *418not in any other manner, either by consent or otherwise, the jurisdiction is not exercised by the appointment of private persons to try the case, and judgment on such trial is not merely erroneous, it is not a judicial proceeding entitled to any respect; it is a sheer usurpation — a mere nulity.

8. Nor would the jurisdiction be exercised by trial by the court, without a jury. Judgment thereon would be a nullity.

YI. Judgment, when necessary, and how proved.

1. When a court is authorized to direct a sale of a defendant’s property, to pay all’claims that may be presented, the court must adjudicate upon such claims ; and the record must show such adjudication, for it is a matter of record, to be shown by the record.

2. It is not sufficient to order a salé, without finding the amount of debts or the sum to be raised, although the court may have appointed private persons to try the claims, who have adjudicated thereon.

If there be no adjudication upon the claims by the court shown by the record, the order to sell is a nullity. It is like a writ of fi. fa. without a previous judgment.

3. When a judgment by default is to be rendered for the plaintiff’s debt, and all other claims upon the defendant are to be adjudicated upon and satisfied, it must be shown that the creditor’s claims were presented to the court, and found by the court to be due. Proof that they were presented to private persons, and found by them to be due, is no proof of a judgment of the court thereon.

4. An entry of judgment must be sufficiently definite to show what is adjudicated by the court.

5. A court cannot, thirty years after the alleged rendition of a judgment, order a record of a judgment to be made up, on an ex parte application, without the proper evidence of such judgment having been rendered.

A record so made up cannot prevail against the record made up, as required by the statute, after the termination of the pro*419ceedings. It cannot supersede the want of a judgment, order of sale, etc.

YII. Judicial sale — When order of court necessary.

1. A sale by private persons, unauthorized by law, and without an order of the court directing them to sell, is a nullity, which cannot be confirmed by the court. It is worse than a sale by the sheriff without a writ oifi.fa.

2. The order of the court must appear on the minutes.

YIII. Conveyance upon judicial sale.

1. The act of 1805, regulating the execution of deeds, requires every conveyance to be perfected by deed, attested, and acknowledged. If the mere sale by the auditors was a conveyance, it was included by the words of the act.

2. Private persons, unauthorized by law, cannot make a conveyance of the land of another, If not ordered by the court so to do, their conveyance is a nullity, which cannot be afterward confirmed by the court; especially when the court is not authorized to revise and confirm the proceedings after judgment.

8. The order directing such unauthorized persons to convey, must appear in the minutes.

IX. Jurisdiction oe courts — To render judgment after defendant’s death.

1. A judgment can only bind those who are actually parties to the judgment, and their privies.

2. A judgment against a dead man binds nobody ; there is no party defendant, nor privy to a party; it is an absolute nullity, in the absence of statutory enactment to the contrary.

8. When a statute authorizes an extraordinary proceeding, and it becomes impossible to comply with its requisitions, in consequence of the death of the defendant, the suit is abated.

In support of these positions they cited the following authorities :

*420Ludlow v. Johnson, 3 Ohio Rep. 557; Lessee of Grey v. Askew, 3 Ohio Rep. 466; McArthur v. Porter, 1 Ohio Rep. 104; Sumner v. Parker, 7 Mass. Rep. 84; 1 Bla. Com. 91 8 Rep. 118; Lessee of Matthews v. Thompson, 3 Ohio Rep. 273; Parker v. Miller, 9 Ohio Rep. 111; Bond v. Patterson, 1 Black. Rep. 34; State Bank v. Hinton, 1 Dev. Rep. 397; 48 Eng. C. L. Rep. 497 ; 4 Phil. Ev. 946; Foot v. Stephens, 17 Wend. Rep. 483; Lessee of Adams v. Jeffries, 12 Ohio Rep. 272; Bloom v. Burdick, 1 Hill’s Rep. 131; Hunt v Wickliffe, 2 Pet. Rep. 201; Voorhees v. Bank U. S., 10 Pet. Rep. 460; Warner v. Webster, 13 Ohio. Rep. 506; 4 Kent’s Com. 435, note; 13 Mass. Rep. 128; 11 Pick. Rep. 341; Edminston v. Edminston, 2 Ohio Rep. 251; Thatcher v. Powell, 6 Wheat. Rep. 119; 3 Phil. Ev. 906, 863; Wattles v. Hyde, 9 Conn. Rep. 10; Coger v. Coger, 2 Dana’s Rep. 270; Case v. Wooley, 6 Dana’s Rep. 20 ; 1 Adol. & Ell. Rep. 18; Renick v. Bank of West Union, 13 Ohio. Rep. 299 ; Bennett’s Lessee v. Williams, 5 Ohio Rep. 463; Goforth’s Lessee v. Longworth, 4 Ohio Rep. 130; Mitchell’s Lessee v. Eyster, 7 Ohio Rep. part 1, 259; Harvey v. Brown, 1 Ohio Rep. (Cond.) 129; The State v. Dawson, 6 Ohio Rep. 253; Goudy v. Shank, 8 Ohio Rep. 415; Bank of Hamilton v. Dudley, 2 Pet. Rep. 522; Bennett v. Ward, 3 Caine’s Rep. 259; Dwarris on Stat. 681, 695; 4 Burr. Rep. 2460; 7 Johns. Rep. 477; Roll’s Ab. 526; Boal’s Lessee v. King, 6 Ohio Rep. 12; Lindsley v. Coats, 1 Ohio Rep. 245; Moore v. Vance, 1 Ohio Rep. 10; Courcier v. Graham, 1 Ohio Rep. 350; Massey v. Thompson, 2 N. & M. Rep. 347; Simonds v. Catlin, 2 Caine’s Rep. 61; Moore v. Farrow, 4 A. K. Marsh. Rep. 41; Stark’s Lessee v. Smith, 5 Ohio Rep. 456; Crocker v. Radcliffe, 1 Const. Rep. 88; Smith v. Pratt, 13 Ohio Rep. 551; Starr v. Trustees of Rochester, 6 Wend. Rep. 564; Arnold v. Fuller, 1 Ohio Rep. 214; Lessee of Massie’s Heirs v. Long, 2 Ohio Rep. 214 , Lessee of McCartney v. Reed, 5 Ohio Rep. 221; Haydock v. Cobb, 5 Day’s Rep. 529; Wilson v. Watson, 1 Pet. C. C. Rep. 269; Stymets v. Brooks, 10 Wend. *421Rep. 206; Woodcock v. Bennett, 1 Cow. Rep. 738; Griswold v. Stewart, 1 Cow. Rep. 458; Thomas v. Smith, 2 Mass. Rep. 479; Macker v. Thomas, 7 Wheat. Rep. 530; Jackson v Esty, 7 Wend. Rep. 148; U. S. Dig. title Abatement, 4, 5; Critchfield v. Porter, 3 Ohio Rep. 519; Smith v. Rice, 11 Mass. Rep. 512; Mills v. Martin, 19 Johns. Rep. 33; Watson v. Spence, 20 Wend. Rep. 265; Lessee of Hickey v. Stewart, 3 How. Rep. 751; Starbuck v. Murray, 5 Wend. Rep. 148; 3 Phil. Ev. 800-1, 826, 868, 904; Harman v. Gould, Wright’s Rep. 709; Ohio v. Daily et al., 14 Ohio Rep. 99; Dows v. Harper, 6 Ohio Rep. 518; Maxsom v. Sawyer, 12 Ohio Rep. 195.

O. M. Spencer, W S. Groesbeck, R. M. Corwin, and G. E. Pugh, for defendant in error, replied to the various objections urged against the defendant’s title, and contended that the proceedings in attachment were valid. They cited the following authorities:

Paine’s Lessee v. Moreland, 15 Ohio Rep. 435; 3 Ohio Rep. 305; 7 Ohio Rep. 2d part, 142; Voorhees v. Bank U. S., 10 Pet. Rep. 471; 9 Ohio Rep. 114; Weyer v. Zane, 3 Ohio Rep. 305; 4 Ohio Rep. 327; 5 Ohio Rep. 524; 11 Ohio Rep. 261; Parker’s Lessor v. Miller, 9 Ohio Rep. 108; Michael v. Eyster, 7 Ohio Rep. 1st part, 258 ; 12 Ohio Rep. 272; Warder v. Painter, 4 Watt’s Rep. 278; 1 Roll’s Ab. 742, 768; 2 Bac. Ab. 450 (Wilson’s Ed.) ; Cro. Eliz. 202; Penhallow v. Doane’s Adm’r, 3 Dall. Rep. 101; 4 Ohio Rep. 133, 154; Wright’s Rep. 566; Roads v. Symmes, 1 Ohio Rep. 316; Stall’s Lessee v. McAlister, 9 Ohio Rep. 20.

Hitchcock, J.

This is a case' of very considerable importance, both on account of the value of the property and of the principles involved. .It has been argued at great length and with much ability by the counsel concerned, and it is certainly involved in some doubt. It is believed, however, that if *422we apply to it the ordinary rules of law, governing cases of this description, there can be no insurmountable difficulty in coming to a decision.

The facts as well as the law of the case were submitted to the decision of the court below, and taking the assignment of errors as indicating the cause of complaint of the plaintiff in error, that complaint is not so much that the court violated any principle of law, in the decision of any particular point, as that upon the whole case the court came to a wrong conclusion. In the argument, however, objections are raised to many items of evidence, or rather to the effect .which was given by the court below to these items of evidence, which objections will be considered in the progress of the examination of the case.

The bill of-exceptions, together with the documents therein referred to, show that on the trial the lessors of the plaintiff proved that they were the lineal heirs of Thomas Cochran, and that he died the latter part of June, 1801. That before his decease he was the legal owner of the premises in controversy; that he left Cincinnati in January, 1801, and with his family arrived at Natchez, and there remained until his death. That from the time of this removal they have been non-residents of the north-w'estern territory, and of the State of Ohio until the year 1840, with the exception of one of them, who visited Cincinnati in 1827.

Having proved these facts the plaintiff rested, and the defendants to prove title in themselves, introduced the record of a suit in attachment in favor of James Smith and James Eindlay, instituted in the court of common pleas of Hamilton county, in February, 1801, against the said Thomas Cochran, in virtue of which the premises in controversy were attached, and such further proceedings were had that the premises were eventually sold and conveyed to James Findlay, under whom the defendants claim title.

To this record many objections were made, and it is insisted by counsel for plaintiff in error that' the whole proceeding is without authority of law, and utterly null and void. If so, *423the premises in controvery still remain, from aught that appears m this case, the property of the lessors of the plaintiffs, and the judgment of the superior court must be reversed. But if, on the other hand, the judgment is merely voidable on account of error, it cannot be impeached in this collateral manner, no matter how numerous the errors.

The principle we understand is this, a title acquired under a void judgment cannot be sustained ; a title acquired under an erroneous judgment will be sustained so long as the judgment remains in force. And under our system the reversal of a judgment will not defeat a title acquired while the judgment is in force. Whether a judgment is voidable depends generally upon the question -whether the court rendering the judgment has jurisdiction. In the case of Lessee of Paine v. Moreland, 15 Ohio Rep. 445, this court say: “The distinction is between the lack of power or want of jurisdiction in the .court, and a wrongful or defective execution of power. In the first instance, all acts of the court not having jurisdiction or power are void, in the latter voidable only. A court then may act, first, without power or jurisdiction ; second, having power or jurisdiction, may exercise it wrongfully; or third, irregularly. In the first instance, the act or judgment of the court is wholly void, and is as though it had not been done. The second is wrong and must be reversed upon error. The third is irregular, and must be corrected by motion.”

This distinction between void and voidable, as applied to judicial proceedings, seems to be fully admitted by counsel, and the effect is to show that the proceeding in the case before the court is utterly void. The first position assumed is that there was no law, at the time these proceeding began, authorizing them, and therefore they are void. These proceedings -were commenced during the existence of the territorial government, and it is not denied but that attachment laws had been adopted by the governor and judges, but it is denied that these officials had power to adopt them. The ordinance for the government of the territory provides that “ the governor *424and judges, or a majority of them, shall adopt and publish in the district, such laws of the original states, civil and criminal, as may be necessary, and best suited to the circumstances of the district, and report them to congress from time to time, which laws shall be enforced in the district until the organization of the general assembly therein, unless disapproved by congress; hut afterward the legislature shall have authority to alter them as they shall see fit.” In this clause there is no restriction, but discretionary power is given to adopt such laws as may be necessary, subject, however, to the disapproval of congress.

In pursuance of the power thus conferred, the governor and judges, on the 1st day of June, 1795, adopted from the statxxtes of Pennsylvania, two laws, one “ allowing domestic attachments,” and the other “ regulating domestic attachments,” to take effect on the 15th of August of the same year. (Chase’s Stat. 141.) On the 15th of July of the same year, a law was adopted from the statutes of New Jersey, “ allowing foreign attachments,” to take effect from the first of October next following. These laxvs remained in force, or were supposed to remain in force, until subsequently repealed by the proper authority. They were recognized as binding by the courts of the territory, and many judicial proceédings were had under them. I infer this from the facts disclosed in the record before us, that in searching the newspapers to ascertain whether publication of notice, in the case of Smith and Findlay v. Cochran, had been made, frequent publications of notices of the pendency of other suits in attachment were found. And a decision that these laws were all void, destroys the foundation of the other suits, as well as of the one now more immediately before the court.

One of the objections to these laws, as I understand it, is that they provide for proceedings not according to the course of the common law, and reference is bad to the second of the articles of compact prescribed in the ordinance of 1787. (Ch. Stat. 58.) That article, so far as this question is concerned, is *425as follows: “ The inhabitants of said territory shall akoays be entitled to the benefit of the writ of habeas corpus, and of the trial by jury; of a proportionate representation of the people in the legislature, and of judicial proceedings, according to the course of the common law.” This article follows a declaration in the ordinance to this effect: “ It is hereby ordained and declared, by the authority aforesaid, that the following articles shall be considered as articles of compact between the original states, and the people and states in the said territory, and forever remain unalterable, unless by common consent.” The principles declared in these articles, and they are of a similar character to principles declared in a bill of rights, are to prevail not only during the territorial government, but for all coming time. They must “ forever remain unaltered.” By the constitution of the state, in the 8fch section of the 8th article it is declared, “ That the right of trial by jury shall be inviolate,” an expression similar to the one cited from the ordinance. If it be a valid objection to the territorial attachment laws, that they authorized proceedings not according to the common law, and are therefore void, the same objection lies against the attachment laws enacted by the state legislature, especially those previous to 1810. This description of laws have existed and been enforced, however, since 1795, and it seems to the court that it is now too late to question their validity, or rather constitutionality. • The construction put upon the ordinance by counsel is too narrow. True, the right of trial by jury is guarded, but it could never have been intended that in every possible case it should have been enjoyed. Judicial proceedings according to the course of the common law, are secured, but this never could have been intended so to restrict the future legislative power of the territory or state, that chancery proceedings could not be authorized, or any other proceedings necessary to the ends of justice. Proceedings by attachment are. not, it is true, according to the course of the common law. They are, under our system, proceedings in rem, intended to subject the property of a debtor to the payment of his debts. But in most *426if not all our laws upon this subject, ample provision has been made for a defendant to come in, make defense, and have a trial as in other eases. Besides, had these laws been inconsistent with the ordinance, we may well suppose the same would have been disapproved by the government of the United States. Prom all these considerations, we are of opinion that the governor and judges had power to adopt attachment, as well as other laws.

Another objection made, in substance, is that the law under which the proceedings in attachment were had, was void for uncertainty, and therefore proceedings under it could not be sustained. The uncertainty consists in this, that the mode of proceeding is not prescribed in the law itself, but reference is made to another law to ascertain this mode of proceeding, and it is said no such other law was in existence. This objection requires of us to examine the several laws upon the subject. As before stated, on the 1st June, 1795, two laws were adopted from the statutes of Pennsylvania, one “ allowing domestic attachments,” and the other “ regulating domestic attachments.” By the first of these laws, an attachment might be issued against the goods and chattels of a defendant, but such attachment was not to be issued except against such person or person’s effects, as, at the time of granting such writs, were not residents of the territory, or were about to remove, or make their escape out of the same (Chase’s Stat. 141). This seems to have been a proceeding under which the property of a defendant was seized, to compel his appearance in court, and to secure the debt due. Upon the appearance of defendant, and the entry of special bail, the case was proceeded in, as if personal service of process had been made. The seizure of the goods, under the attachment, gave the court jurisdiction.

The law regulating domestic attachments seems to have been designed, in its first section, to confer jurisdiction by this description of process upon justices of the peace. But in the second section, it is provided that if, upon examination, the justice shall find “ that there is a just debt due to any one person *427from the defendant, exceeding the sum of twelve dollars, tl^n, and in every such, case, the said justice of the peace shall no further proceed, but shall deliver and certify to the prothonotary of the court of common pleas, for the same, the said attachments, and all the proceedings thereon.” This being done, the justices of the court of common pleas are authorized to' issue an attachment “ to the sheriff of the county, directing him to attach all the goods, chattels, rights and interests, lands, tenements, and hereditaments of the said defendant, within his bailiwick ” (Chase’s Stat. 142). The next law upon this subject was adopted from the statutes of New Jersey, on the 15th July, 1795, allowing foreign attachments (Chase’s Stat. 197). The first section provides that the lands, tenements, goods,- chattels, etc., of a person or persons not resident of the territory, may be attached for the payment of any just debt, etc., by writ or writs issued out of the general court, any circuit court, or court of common pleas; “ and as early as may be, shall and may be proceeded against, in the same manner as is directed against the lands, tenements, hereditaments, and estates of absconding debtors, except where otherwise herein directed.”

It is urged by plaintiff’s counsel that there was no such law in force as is here referred to, as appliable to the estates of absconding debtors; and that therefore this was a void enactment. The only law in force, so far as appears upon the statute book, relative to attaching the lands of an absconding debtor, is the second section of the act before referred to, “ regulating domestic attachments.” There might have been some other adopted, but not published; or, if published, it may not have got into the statute book. But does it therefore follow that if there was no such law, the law of the 15th July, 1795, must be void ? The imperfection of a law will not render it void, unless it is so imperfect as to render it utterly impossible to execute it. Is such the fact with respect to the law of the 15th July, 1795 ? The substance of the first section has been already noticed. The second section provides that before the writ is issued, an *428affidavit shall be made, and filed in the clerk’s office, which shall contain certain facts, as pointed out in the section.

, The third section relates to two or more persons, whether partnership debtors or otherwise. Prescribes the manner in which their property shall be attached, and provides that the lands, etc., of such debtors, or either of them, may be taken for the satisfaction of any just debt, or other demand, “ and may he sold to satisfy the same.”

The fourth section provides that no judgment shall be entered until the expiration of twelve months. In the meantime notice of the pendency of the suit is to be published, and the form of the notice is prescribed. By it the debtor is to be notified that unless “ he shall appear, by himself or his attorney, to give special bail to answer such suit, that then judgment will be entered against such debtor or debtors by default, and' the estate or estates attached be sold for the satisfaction of all creditors who shall appear to be justly entitled to a demand thereon, and shall apply for that purpose.”

And the last section secures to the defendant in attachment the right, at any time within twelve months after the attachment shall have been determined, to contest by suit any claim which may have been allowed against him, and paid, and if wrongfully paid to recover back the amount.

Now this law does not, it is true, go so far into detail as to describe every particular step to be taken from the commencement to the final end of the suit, but it authorizes the issuing of an attachment, the seizure of the property of the debtor, a judgment against him, the liquidation of all claims presented against him, the sale of the property attached, and the distribution of the avails amongst the creditors. It is a law which may be executed. The mode of liquidating the claims, of the sale of the property, and other matters relative to the business, might well be provided for by rules of court. And that such was the fact we may well infer from the circumstance that, when this act was repealed by the territorial law of 1802, the repeal, *429ing clause contains this proviso, “ That nothing herein contained shall affect the- proceedings in any attachment now pending and undetermined; but the same shall be continued, and conducted according to the rules and practice established under the acts of the territory heretofore in force.” What'these rules were, and what this practice was, wrn cannot know at this distance of time, nearly fifty years, or perhaps more, having elapsed since the same were established. They were such, however, as were recognized as obligatory by the law-maldng power. All the knowlege we can have of them must be derived from the records of the court, and these are, generally speaking, somewhat imperfect. Counsel for the plaintiff seem to suppose that the course of practice adopted in the case now before us was in conformity with and controlled by the law of 1802. It would, perhaps, be as reasonable to suppose that that law was, in many of its details, but the adoption by the territorial legislature of the rules and practice which had previously prevailed in the territorial courts, in like cases. This, however, is all matter of conjecture. In the opinion of the court, the law of the 15th July, 1795, was not void, but under its provisions, the courts of the territory might acquire jurisdiction in cases of attachment.

It is further objected to the proceedings in attachment, that, admitting the attachment laws adopted by the governor and judges to have been in force at the time these proceedings were instituted, still that there was no writ or affidavit as required, and therefore the court did. not acquire jurisdiction. The facts relative to this part of the case appear to be these, as collected from the record and evidence in the case. An affidavit as required by the law, was made before one of the justices of the court of common pleas, on the 31st of January, 1801, upon which the writ issued, returnable at the February term following. This affidavit is not inserted in the record, but is produced in evidence. The clerk of the court, who issued the writ instead of dating it on the day on which it was issued, dated it as of the last day of the preceding term of the court, to wit: *430the 21st of November, 1801. Whether such was the usual practice of that day I do not know. It might have been, or the clerk might have supposed it necessary, under the phraseology of the attachment law, that the lands, tenements, etc., might be attached, “ by a writ or writs to be issued out of the general court, or any circuit court, or court of common pleas,” etc.

If we consider this case, as it appears from the -record, and assume the 21st of November to have been the date of the writ, a question arises as to the sufficiency of the writ, it not being recited that affidavit had been made, and no affidavit appearing upon the record. The law authorized the writ to be issued upon affidavit filed with the clerk, but there was no law prescribing that this affidavit should be made part of the record. The writ recites, “ whereas James Smith and James Findlay have testified to the court of common pleas, at Cincinnati, in the county of Hamilton aforesaid,” etc. Now if we proceed upon the assumption that the writ must be issued out of the court, as if it were the act of the court or done by its order, the recital shows that before it was issued, preliminary proof was made.

How^made ? We must suppose it to have been made in the manner required by law. Taking the record itself then, it suf ficiently appears that an affidavit was filed. Taking the other evidence in the ease, however, and admitting it to be competent, what does it show ? simply that an affidavit was made as the law directs before a justice of the court of common pleas, and was filed with the clerk. It bears date, however, at a time subsequent to the date of the writ. Further than this, it appears that the writ itself, though dated in November, 1800, was not actually issued until the latter part of January, 1801, and after the date of the affidavit. It is objected, however, that it should have been issued “ from the court,” or by its order. By a law “ establishing courts of judicature,” which took effect Oct. 1, 1795, in the 6th section it is provided “ that every of said justices shall be and are hereby empowered to grant, under *431the seal of their respective courts, writs of replevin, writs of partition, writs of view, and all other writs and process upon the said pleas and actions, cognizable in the said respective courts, as occasion,” etc. It may have been, that under the cotemporaneous construction of this section of the statute, the justice of the court of common pleas, before whom the affidavit was made, authorized, sp far as any authorization was necessary, the issuing the attachment in this case. How far this practice of dating writs, as of the previous term of the court, prevailed in-the territorial courts I do not know, nor is it necessary for us to inquire. It was probably found to be attended with inconvenience, as we find at the first session of the general assembly under the state government, in an “ act organizing judicial courts,” it was provided, “ that all writs and process shall run in the style of the State of Ohio,-county, ss, shall bear test in the name of the presiding judge, be sealed with the seal, and signed by the clerk of the proper court, and shall be dated on the day on which the same may issue.”

Upon a careful examination, we are satisfied that under the attachment law then in force, a writ of attachment was properly issued from the court of common pleas of Hamilton county, at the suit of Smith and Findlay v. Thomas Cochran, that the same was levied upon the land in controversy, and the writ properly returned, whereby that court acquired jurisdiction of the case, and were authorized to proceed therein.

The next ground of objection is that notice of the pendency of the suit was not given as required by law. If this were true it would undoubtedly render the proceeding and judgment erroneous, but would it render them void ? This question was fully considered in the case of Paine’s Lessee v. Moreland, 15 Ohio Rep. 435, in which it is expressly decided, that the court acquires jurisdiction in attachment, by the issuing of process, predicated upon the requisite affidavit, and the attaching of property; and if, after thus obtaining jurisdiction, the court proceed to render judgment, without the publication of notice, such judgment is not void, and cannot be impeached collaterally,-but *432must be reversed upon writ of error. This decision is fully sustained by the supreme court of the United States, in the case of Voorhees v. Bank U. S., 10 Peters Rep. 449. Under the law in force at the time of these proceedings it was not necessary that proof of notice should constitute any part of the record. That law required that a publication should be made in a newspaper printed in the territory, in one printed in Kentucky, and one printed at the seat of government of the United .States. It is in proof that publication was made in a newspaper printed in the territory, and it would not be too much to presume that the law was complied with, as to the other publi cations. But as the judgment cannot be collaterally impeached on this ground, it is unnecessary to dwell further on the point.

It is further objected that there was no judgment. One of the transcripts of records produced in evidence, show's that there was a formal judgment. But it is claimed that this is of no avail, inasmuch as there had been a previous record made, and in that record this judgment did not appear. It seems that the court of common pleas of Hamilton county, at the November term,- 1886, upon inspection of the docket entries, and the record previously made, and finding the latter to be imperfect, directed the clerk to make a more perfect record, and where, upon the docket entry at a particular term, the letters “ judg’t ” are written, to enter the judgment in form, and where, in the same term, the entry is made “ Report of auditors filed, order of sale to issue,” to enter such order in full, etc. The whole amount of this order of the court, of which much complaint is made, is, that the'clerk made out a correct record from the papers on file and the docket entries in the case. I cannot see any thing wrong in this. It seems to me to have been proper, and such course is sustained by this court, in the case of Mitchell v. Eyster, 7 Ohio Rep. pt. 1, 258. It is said that the word “ judgment ” written in full upon the docket, or abbreviated, is of no avail and as nothing, but that every judgment must be formally entered before it can be noticed. If so, then some of our sister states, and especially in the State *433of Pennsylvania, there are but few valid judgments. For, in most of the transcripts of record which I have seen from that state, there is no evidence of any judgment, except the letters “judg’t.” And to this day in the county in which these pro ceedings were had, in most of the transcripts which are sent to this court from one of the inferior courts, there is no evidence of any judgment except the word “judgment” or the letters “ judg’t.”

The next objection is that there was no order of sale. This is not true in point of fact if what is called the new record is considered as being in evidence.

It is next claimed that the death of Cochran, before the rendition of judgment, put an end to the proceedings, and that a judgment subsequently rendered is void; and it is further insisted, as a general principle, that a judgment against a dead man is void. The death of a party, before judgment, is, in the books, said to render the judgment erroneous, and is one of those errors in fact for which a judgment may be reversed. If void, why reverse it ? I take the law to be this : such a judgment may, in some instances, be held to be void as to strangers, but is merely erroneous as to parties and privies, and this is the distinction taken in 4th Cowen’s Rep. 286, to which we have been-referred. Now the lessors of the plaintiffs are the heirs of Cochran. They stand in the relation of privies to this judgment. But were it otherwise, inasmuch as this attachment proceeding is a proceeding in rem, I should be unwilling to say that the death of the debtor, after the property is attached, would prevent the court from proceeding to liquidate the claims presented, and distribute the avails of the property according to the meaning and intent of the law under which the proceedings were had. To put this matter beyond controversy, the legislature, in subsequent attachment laws, have expressly provided that the death of the debtor shall not put a stop to the proceedings.

Another objection is that there was no deed properly executed to vest the land in the purchaser. The record shows that *434auditors were appointed to hear and adjust the claims of creditors. This was certainly a convenient way of adjusting these claims, and as the law made no provision on the subject, by a rule of practice, the court might well adopt it. And this was probably in the mind of the territorial legislature when the proviso to the repealing law of 1802, which has been already referred to, was adopted. These auditors made their report to the court, upon which judgment/was entered, and an order of sale made. This was directed to the auditors. For this it is said there was no law. In fact the law, so far as we know any thing about it, although it directed that the property should be sold, gave no directions as to the manner of sale, nor as to the person or persons by whom the sale should be effected. This was left to the discretion of the court. The property had been attached, it was in the custody of the law, the court were bound to see that the avails were distributed. To effect this object, they directed the auditors to make the sale. I am not aware that, in thus proceeding, they were guilty of exercising any greater excess of power than this court sometimes does, in directing sales to be made by master commissioners in chancery. For it is not within my recollection that we have ever had any statute authorizing property to be so sold in such manner, al though we have adopted the practice as being incidental to the powers of a court of chancery. In pursuance of this order of sale, the auditors made sale and executed a deed to the pur chaser, which was acknowledged in open court, and the whole was approved by the court ordering the sale. So far I see nothing wrong.

But it is said, and such appears to be the fact, this deed was without witnesses. Is it void on this account ? At the time this deed was executed, it was required, in ordinary cases, if not in every case, that a deed should be attested by two subscribing witnesses. But from 1795 to 1805, no witnesses were necessary, provided the deed was acknowledged as the law required. Lessee of Moore v. Vance, 1 Ohio R. 1. Such was the law at the time these proceedings in attachment were instituted, *435When the law under which these proceedings were instituted, was repealed, it was under this proviso, “ That nothing herein contained shall affect the proceedings, on any attachment now pending and undetermined, but the same shall be continued according to the rules and practice established under the acts of the territory heretofore in force.” This saving clause may have been construed to extend as well to the proceedings after judgment, in the disposition of the property, as to the proceedings before judgment; -nor would this be a forced construction, as the case must-be continued in court until the property attached had been disposed of, and the avails distributed. At the time these proceedings were instituted, the law did not require, for the validity of a deed, that the same should be attested by witnesses, and it may with much plausibility be urged, that for this particular class of cases this principle of law was continued in force. When we consider that under the attachment law of July, 1795, there was no provision made as to the manner in which property should be conveyed after it had been .sold, although the sale was expressly required; when we consider further, that at the time of the institution of these proceedings no attesting witnesses were necessary to the validity of a deed, and further, that this conveyance was made under the direction and approval of the court having jurisdiction of the whole matter, we are not prepared to say, that this deed was no evidence of title. It was but one of the items in the course of judicial proceedings, by which the property of Thomas Cochran was ■appropriated to the payment of his debts. There can be no -doubt that the property was, by the attachment, in the custody of the law ; that it has been sold pursuant to the law; that it was purchased by those under whom the defendants claim title; that it has been in their possession, and in the possession of those under whom they claim, for about forty years, and as before remarked, we are not prepared to say that they have not the legal title.

The judgment of the Superior Court is affirmed.

Read, J., dissented.
